title: (x) Russian Constructivism font - various {gang}
content:
I'm looking for a Russian Constructivism type Font. Something "blocky" any suggestions.   
   
email me [rikeswon@aol.com](mailto:rikeswon@aol.com)
author: samiam

comments.content: You could try [East Bloc](http://web.archive.org/web/20090430074147/http:/www.eyewire.com/cgi-bin/WebObjects/View.woa/wa/viewProduct?product=527) by Image Club Graphics.
And there's some vintage stuff in the Architype Collection over at Quay's and Sack's [The Foundry](http://web.archive.org/web/20090430074147/http:/www.foundrytypes.co.uk/).
Or [Stenberg](http://web.archive.org/web/20090430074147/http:/www.myfonts.com/FontFamily4393.html), which has a lovely inline variant.

01:10 - 01:04 = 6 minutes   
Stephen, you're tripping over your own type-ID prowess.   
   
hhp

Wow. Rodchenko is pretty sweet. I do like the   
rawness of P22s Constructivist but to date I   
haven't seen anything as raw as Rodchenko's   
actual work.   
   
Rodchenko's character widths are all over the   
place and lend a handmade feel to his otherwise   
geometric work. I'll post a sample sometime of   
what I mean.

[House](http://web.archive.org/web/20090430074147/http:/www.houseindustries.com/) just released a Cyrillic set of Chalet, which is   
beautiful. Somehow the 60s flavor of Chalet fits perfectly   
with the Cyrillic alphabet. Worth a look.

And then there's the heirs to Russian Constructivism with contemporary interpretations. Mark van Wageningen's **Gagarin** family at [2Rebels](http://web.archive.org/web/20090430074147/http:/www.2rebels.com/) and Pierre di Sciullo's **FF Minimum** from the [FontFont Collection](http://web.archive.org/web/20090430074147/http:/www.fontfont.com/shop/) are interesting takes on the subject. And the very constructivist **FF Marten** by Marten Wenzel, also a [FontFont](http://web.archive.org/web/20090430074147/http:/www.fontfont.com/shop/), has a cyrillic variant.

Kraft und Stil by andreas lindkvist.   
 [http://www.lindkvist.com/](http://web.archive.org/web/20090430074147/http:/www.lindkvist.com/)
mr. coles, i am truly amazed. on a slightly different note, what about books on the subject? i've seen plenty that have a small section on constructivism, but none dedicated solely to it.
Just stumbled into [Aleksei](http://web.archive.org/web/20090430074147/http:/www.t26.com/changeyourface.htm) over at T-26.

Could somebody please make a Russian constructivist font and call it Slutskaya?
